Text

In the year 1878 [I]0-i took [my]0-i degree of Doctor of Medicine of [the University of [London]2-london]1-the university of london , and proceeded to [Netley]3-netley to go through the course prescribed for [surgeons in [the army]204-the army]203-surgeons in the army . Having completed [my]0-i studies [there]205-there , [I]0-i was duly attached to [the Fifth Northumberland Fusiliers]206-the fifth northumberland fusiliers as [Assistant Surgeon]207-assistant surgeon . [The regiment]208-the regiment was stationed in [India]4-india at the time , and before [I]0-i could join [it]208-the regiment , the second Afghan war had broken out . On landing at [Bombay]5-bombay , [I]0-i learned that [[my]0-i corps]209-my corps had advanced through the passes , and was already deep in [[the enemy]210-the enemy 's country]211-the enemy 's country . [I]0-i followed , however , with [many other officers who were in the same situation as [myself]0-i]212-many other officers who were in the same situation as myself , and succeeded in reaching [Candahar]6-candahar in safety , where [I]0-i found [[my]0-i regiment]213-my regiment , and at once entered upon [my]0-i new duties .

The campaign brought honours and promotion to [many]214-many , but for [me]0-i it had nothing but misfortune and disaster . [I]0-i was removed from [[my]0-i brigade]215-my brigade and attached to [the Berkshires]7-the berkshires , with whom [I]0-i served at the fatal battle of [Maiwand]8-maiwand . There [I]0-i was struck on the shoulder by a Jezail bullet , which shattered the bone and grazed the subclavian artery . [I]0-i should have fallen into the hands of [the murderous Ghazis]105-the murderous ghazis had it not been for the devotion and courage shown by [Murray]106-murray , [[my]0-i orderly]216-my orderly , who threw [me]0-i across a pack - horse , and succeeded in bringing [me]0-i safely to [the British lines]217-the british lines .

Worn with pain , and weak from the prolonged hardships which [I]0-i had undergone , [I]0-i was removed , with [a great train of [wounded sufferers]219-wounded sufferers]218-a great train of wounded sufferers , to [the base hospital at [Peshawar]9-peshawar]220-the base hospital at peshawar . Here [I]0-i rallied , and had already improved so far as to be able to walk about the wards , and even to bask a little upon the verandah , when [I]0-i was struck down by enteric fever , that curse of [[our]221-our Indian possessions]222-our indian possessions . For months [my]0-i life was despaired of , and when at last [I]0-i came to [myself]0-i and became convalescent , [I]0-i was so weak and emaciated that [a medical board]223-a medical board determined that not a day should be lost in sending [me]0-i back to [England]10-england . [I]0-i was dispatched , accordingly , in [the troopship " Orontes]1313-the troopship " orontes , "[223-a medical board] and landed a month later on [[Portsmouth]11-portsmouth jetty]224-portsmouth jetty , with [my]0-i health irretrievably ruined , but with permission from [a paternal government]225-a paternal government to spend the next nine months in attempting to improve it .

[I]0-i had neither kith nor kin in [England]10-england , and was therefore as free as air - or as free as an income of eleven shillings and sixpence a day will permit [a man]226-a man to be . Under such circumstances , [I]0-i naturally gravitated to [London]2-london , [that great cesspool into which all the loungers and [idlers of the Empire]228-idlers of the empire are irresistibly drained]227-that great cesspool into which all the loungers and idlers of the empire are irresistibly drained . There [I]0-i stayed for some time at [a private hotel in [the Strand]12-the strand]229-a private hotel in the strand , leading a comfortless , meaningless existence , and spending such money as [I]0-i had , considerably more freely than [I]0-i ought . So alarming did the state of [my]0-i finances become , that [I]0-i soon realized that [I]0-i must either leave [the metropolis]230-the metropolis and rusticate somewhere in [the country]231-the country , or that [I]0-i must make a complete alteration in [my]0-i style of living . Choosing the latter alternative , [I]0-i began by making up [my]0-i mind to leave [the hotel]232-the hotel , and to take up [[my]0-i quarters]233-my quarters in [some less pretentious and less expensive domicile]234-some less pretentious and less expensive domicile .

On the very day that [I]0-i had come to this conclusion , [I]0-i was standing at [the Criterion Bar]235-the criterion bar , when [some one]236-some one tapped [me]0-i on the shoulder , and turning round [I]0-i recognized [young Stamford]107-stamford , who had been [a dresser under [me]0-i at [Barts]13-barts]237-a dresser under me at barts . The sight of a friendly face in [the great wilderness of [London]2-london]238-the great wilderness of london is a pleasant thing indeed to [a lonely man]239-a lonely man . In old days [Stamford]107-stamford had never been [a particular crony of mine]240-a particular crony of mine , but now [I]0-i hailed [him]107-stamford with enthusiasm , and [he]107-stamford , in [his]107-stamford turn , appeared to be delighted to see [me]0-i . In the exuberance of [my]0-i joy , [I]0-i asked [him]107-stamford to lunch with [me]0-i at [the Holborn]14-the holborn , and [we]241-we started off together in a hansom .

" Whatever have [you]0-i been doing with [yourself]0-i , [Watson]108-dr. watson ? " [You]0-i are as thin as a lath and as brown as a nut . "[107-stamford]

This was [a lofty chamber]257-a lofty chamber , lined and littered with countless bottles . "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work] [He]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work seized [me]0-i by the coat - sleeve in [his]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work eagerness , and drew [me]0-i over to the table at which [he]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work had been working . " Now , [I]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work add this small quantity of blood to a litre of water . [You]0-i perceive that the resulting mixture has the appearance of pure water . The proportion of blood can not be more than one in a million . [I]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work have no doubt , however , that [we]1349-us shall be able to obtain the characteristic reaction . "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work] As [he]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work spoke , [he]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work threw into the vessel a few white crystals , and then added some drops of a transparent fluid . In an instant the contents assumed a dull mahogany colour , and a brownish dust was precipitated to the bottom of the glass jar .

" Ha ! ha ! "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work] [he]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work cried , clapping [his]258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work hands , and looking as delighted as [a child with a new toy]261-a child with a new toy . " What do [you]0-i think of that ? "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work]

" It seems to be a very delicate test , "[0-i] [I]0-i remarked .

" Beautiful ! beautiful ! The old Guiacum test was very clumsy and uncertain . So is the microscopic examination for blood corpuscles . The latter is valueless if the stains are a few hours old . Now , this appears to act as well whether the blood is old or new . Had this test been invented , there are [hundreds of men now walking the earth who would long ago have paid the penalty of [their]1350-hundreds of men now walking the earth who would long ago have paid the penalty of their crimes crimes]1350-hundreds of men now walking the earth who would long ago have paid the penalty of their crimes . "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work]

" Indeed ! "[0-i] [I]0-i murmured .

" Criminal cases are continually hinging upon that one point . [A man]226-a man is suspected of a crime months perhaps after it has been committed . [His]226-a man linen or clothes are examined , and brownish stains discovered upon them . Are they blood stains , or mud stains , or rust stains , or fruit stains , or what are they ? That is a question which has puzzled [many an expert]1352-many an expert , and why ? Because there was no reliable test . Now [we]1353-we have the [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes ' test , and there will no longer be any difficulty . "[258-one student in the room , who was bending over a distant table absorbed in his work]

[We]270-we met next day as [he]107-stamford had arranged , and inspected [the rooms at [No . 221B]20-no . 221b , [Baker Street]19-baker street , of which [he]107-stamford had spoken at [our]270-we meeting]271-the rooms at no . 221b , baker street , of which he had spoken at our meeting . That very evening [I]0-i moved [my]0-i things round from [the hotel]232-the hotel , and on the following morning [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes followed [me]0-i with several boxes and portmanteaus . For a day or two [we]270-we were busily employed in unpacking and laying out [[our]270-we property]276-our property to the best advantage . That done , [we]270-we gradually began to settle down and to accommodate [ourselves]270-we to [our]270-we new surroundings .

[Holmes]110-holmes was certainly not [a difficult man to live with]277-a difficult man to live with . [He]110-holmes was quiet in [his]110-holmes ways , and [his]110-holmes habits were regular . It was rare for [him]110-holmes to be up after ten at night , and [he]110-holmes had invariably breakfasted and gone out before [I]0-i rose in the morning . Sometimes [he]110-holmes spent [his]110-holmes day at [the chemical laboratory]256-the chemical laboratory , sometimes in [the dissecting - rooms]1344-the dissecting - rooms , and occasionally in long walks , which appeared to take [him]110-holmes into [the lowest portions of [the City]281-the city]280-the lowest portions of the city . Nothing could exceed [his]110-holmes energy when the working fit was upon [him]110-holmes ; but now and again a reaction would seize [him]110-holmes , and for days on end [he]110-holmes would lie upon the sofa in [the sitting - room]282-the sitting - room , hardly uttering a word or moving a muscle from morning to night . On these occasions [I]0-i have noticed such a dreamy , vacant expression in [his]110-holmes eyes , that [I]0-i might have suspected [him]110-holmes of being addicted to the use of some narcotic , had not the temperance and cleanliness of [his]110-holmes whole life forbidden such a notion .

As the weeks went by , [my]0-i interest in [him]110-holmes and [my]0-i curiosity as to [his]110-holmes aims in life , gradually deepened and increased . [His]110-holmes very person and appearance were such as to strike the attention of [the most casual observer]283-the most casual observer . In height [he]110-holmes was rather over six feet , and so excessively lean that [he]110-holmes seemed to be considerably taller . [His]110-holmes eyes were sharp and piercing , save during those intervals of torpor to which [I]0-i have alluded ; and [his]110-holmes thin , hawk - like nose gave [his]110-holmes whole expression an air of alertness and decision . [His]110-holmes chin , too , had the prominence and squareness which mark [the man of determination]284-the man of determination . [His]110-holmes hands were invariably blotted with ink and stained with chemicals , yet [he]110-holmes was possessed of extraordinary delicacy of touch , as [I]0-i frequently had occasion to observe when [I]0-i watched [him]110-holmes manipulating [his]110-holmes fragile philosophical instruments .

[The reader]285-the reader may set [me]0-i down as [a hopeless busybody]286-a hopeless busybody , when [I]0-i confess how much [this man]287-this man stimulated [my]0-i curiosity , and how often [I]0-i endeavoured to break through the reticence which [he]110-holmes showed on all that concerned [himself]110-holmes . Before pronouncing judgment , however , be it remembered , how objectless was [my]0-i life , and how little there was to engage [my]0-i attention . [My]0-i health forbade [me]0-i from venturing out unless the weather was exceptionally genial , and [I]0-i had [[no friends]288-no friends who would call upon [me]0-i and break the monotony of [my]0-i daily existence]289-no friends who would call upon me and break the monotony of my daily existence . Under these circumstances , [I]0-i eagerly hailed the little mystery which hung around [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion , and spent much of [my]0-i time in endeavouring to unravel it .

[He]287-this man was not studying medicine . [He]287-this man had [himself]287-this man , in reply to a question , confirmed [Stamford]107-stamford 's opinion upon that point . Neither did [he]287-this man appear to have pursued any course of reading which might fit [him]287-this man for a degree in science or any other recognized portal which would give [him]287-this man an entrance into [the learned world]291-the learned world . Yet [his]287-this man zeal for certain studies was remarkable , and within eccentric limits [his]287-this man knowledge was so extraordinarily ample and minute that [his]287-this man observations have fairly astounded [me]0-i . Surely [no man]292-no man would work so hard or attain such precise information unless [he]287-this man had some definite end in view . [Desultory readers]293-desultory readers are seldom remarkable for the exactness of [their]293-desultory readers learning . [No man]292-no man burdens [his]287-this man mind with small matters unless [he]287-this man has some very good reason for doing so .

[His]287-this man ignorance was as remarkable as [his]287-this man knowledge . Of contemporary literature , philosophy and politics [he]287-this man appeared to know next to nothing . Upon [my]0-i quoting [Thomas Carlyle]117-thomas carlyle , [he]287-this man inquired in the naivest way who [he]287-this man might be and what [he]287-this man had done . [My]0-i surprise reached a climax , however , when [I]0-i found incidentally that [he]287-this man was ignorant of the Copernican Theory and of the composition of the Solar System . That [any civilized human being in this nineteenth century]295-any civilized human being in this nineteenth century should not be aware that [the earth]296-the earth travelled round the sun appeared to be to [me]0-i such an extraordinary fact that [I]0-i could hardly realize it .

" [You]0-i appear to be astonished , "[287-this man] [he]287-this man said , smiling at [my]0-i expression of surprise . " Now that [I]287-this man do know it [I]287-this man shall do [my]287-this man best to forget it . "[287-this man]

" To forget it ! "[287-this man]

" [You]0-i see , "[287-this man] [he]287-this man explained , " [I]287-this man consider that [a man]226-a man 's brain originally is like [a little empty attic]1373-a little empty attic , and [you]0-i have to stock [it]1373-a little empty attic with such furniture as [you]0-i choose . [A fool]1374-a fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that [he]1374-a fool comes across , so that the knowledge which might be useful to [him]1374-a fool gets crowded out , or at best is jumbled up with a lot of other things so that [he]1374-a fool has a difficulty in laying [his]1374-a fool hands upon it . " But the Solar System ! "[0-i] [I]0-i protested .

" What the deuce is it to [me]297-he ? "[297-he] [he]297-he interrupted impatiently ; " [you]0-i say that [we]298-we go round the sun . If [we]298-we went round the moon it would not make a pennyworth of difference to [me]297-he or to [my]297-he work . "[297-he]

[I]0-i was on the point of asking [him]297-he what that work might be , but something in [his]297-he manner showed [me]0-i that the question would be an unwelcome one . [SHERLOCK HOLMES]110-holmes - [his]110-holmes limits .

1 . Knowledge of Literature . - Nil . 2 . Philosophy . - Nil . 3 . Astronomy . - Nil . 4 . Politics . - Feeble . 5 . Botany . - Variable . Well up in belladonna , opium , and poisons generally . [He]297-he appears to know every detail of every horror perpetrated in the century . 10 . Plays the violin well . 11 . "[0-i]

[I]0-i see that [I]0-i have alluded above to [his]297-he powers upon the violin . These were very remarkable , but as eccentric as all [his]297-he other accomplishments . That [he]297-he could play pieces , and difficult pieces , [I]0-i knew well , because at [my]0-i request [he]297-he has played [me]0-i some of [Mendelssohn]118-mendelssohn 's Lieder , and other favourites . When left to [himself]297-he , however , [he]297-he would seldom produce any music or attempt any recognized air . Leaning back in [his]297-he arm - chair of an evening , [he]297-he would close [his]297-he eyes and scrape carelessly at the fiddle which was thrown across [his]297-he knee . Sometimes the chords were sonorous and melancholy . Occasionally they were fantastic and cheerful . Clearly they reflected the thoughts which possessed [him]297-he , but whether the music aided those thoughts , or whether the playing was simply the result of a whim or fancy was more than [I]0-i could determine . [I]0-i might have rebelled against these exasperating solos had it not been that [he]297-he usually terminated them by playing in quick succession a whole series of [my]0-i favourite airs as a slight compensation for the trial upon [my]0-i patience .

During the first week or so [we]300-we had [no callers]301-no callers , and [I]0-i had begun to think that [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion was as friendless a man as [I]0-i was [myself]0-i . One morning [a young girl]306-a young girl called , fashionably dressed , and stayed for half an hour or more . " [I]110-holmes have to use [this room]1378-this room as [a place of business]1379-a place of business , "[110-holmes] [he]110-holmes said , " and [these people]1380-these people are [[my]110-holmes clients]1381-my clients . "[110-holmes] Again [I]0-i had an opportunity of asking [him]110-holmes a point blank question , and again [my]0-i delicacy prevented [me]0-i from forcing [another man]316-another man to confide in [me]0-i . [I]0-i imagined at the time that [he]110-holmes had some strong reason for not alluding to it , but [he]110-holmes soon dispelled the idea by coming round to the subject of [his]110-holmes own accord .

It was upon the 4th of March , as [I]0-i have good reason to remember , that [I]0-i rose somewhat earlier than usual , and found that [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes had not yet finished [his]110-holmes breakfast . [The landlady]317-the landlady had become so accustomed to [my]0-i late habits that [my]0-i place had not been laid nor [my]0-i coffee prepared . With the unreasonable petulance of [mankind]1370-mankind [I]0-i rang the bell and gave a curt intimation that [I]0-i was ready . Then [I]0-i picked up a magazine from the table and attempted to while away the time with it , while [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion munched silently at [his]243-my companion toast . One of the articles had a pencil mark at the heading , and [I]0-i naturally began to run [my]0-i eye through it .

Its somewhat ambitious title was " The Book of Life , "[320-an observant man] and it attempted to show how much [an observant man]320-an observant man might learn by an accurate and systematic examination of all that came in [his]320-an observant man way . It struck [me]0-i as being a remarkable mixture of shrewdness and of absurdity . The reasoning was close and intense , but the deductions appeared to [me]0-i to be far - fetched and exaggerated . [The writer]321-the writer claimed by a momentary expression , a twitch of a muscle or a glance of an eye , to fathom [a man]226-a man 's inmost thoughts . Deceit , according to [him]321-the writer , was an impossibility in the case of [one trained to observation and analysis]323-one trained to observation and analysis . [His]321-the writer conclusions were as infallible as so many propositions of Euclid . So startling would [his]321-the writer results appear to the uninitiated that until [they]324-they learned the processes by which [he]321-the writer had arrived at [them]324-they [they]324-they might well consider [him]321-the writer as [a necromancer]325-a necromancer .

" From a drop of water , "[321-the writer] said [the writer]321-the writer , " [a logician]1382-a logician could infer the possibility of an Atlantic or a Niagara without having seen or heard of one or the other . So all life is a great chain , the nature of which is known whenever [we]1383-we are shown a single link of it . Like all other arts , the Science of Deduction and Analysis is one which can only be acquired by long and patient study nor , is life long enough to allow [any mortal]1384-any mortal to attain the highest possible perfection in it . Before turning to those moral and mental aspects of the matter which present the greatest difficulties , let [the enquirer]1385-the enquirer begin by mastering more elementary problems . Let [him]1385-the enquirer , on meeting [a fellow - mortal]1386-a fellow - mortal , learn at a glance to distinguish the history of [the man]1387-the man , and the trade or profession to which [he]1385-the enquirer belongs . Puerile as such an exercise may seem , it sharpens the faculties of observation , and teaches one where to look and what to look for . By [a man]226-a man 's finger nails , by [his]226-a man coat - sleeve , by [his]226-a man boot , by [his]226-a man trouser knees , by the callosities of [his]226-a man forefinger and thumb , by [his]226-a man expression , by [his]226-a man shirt cuffs - by each of these things [a man]226-a man 's calling is plainly revealed . That all [united]1390-united should fail to enlighten [the competent enquirer]1391-the competent enquirer in any case is almost inconceivable . "[321-the writer]

" What ineffable twaddle ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried , slapping the magazine down on the table , " [I]0-i never read such rubbish in [my]0-i life . "[0-i]

" What is it ? "[110-holmes] asked [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes .

" [I]0-i see that [you]110-holmes have read it since [you]110-holmes have marked it . [I]0-i do n't deny that it is smartly written . It irritates [me]0-i though . " [You]110-holmes would lose [your]110-holmes money , "[110-holmes] [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes remarked calmly . " As for the article [I]110-holmes wrote it [myself]110-holmes . "[110-holmes]

" [You]110-holmes ! "[0-i]

" Yes , [I]110-holmes have a turn both for observation and for deduction . "[110-holmes]

" And how ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked involuntarily .

[Number 3 , [Lauriston Gardens]21-lauriston gardens]348-number 3 , lauriston gardens wore an ill - omened and minatory look . [It]348-number 3 , lauriston gardens was one of four which stood back some little way from [the street]329-the street , two being occupied and two empty . [A small garden]350-a small garden sprinkled over with a scattered eruption of sickly plants separated each of [these houses]351-these houses from [the street]329-the street , and was traversed by a narrow pathway , yellowish in colour , and consisting apparently of a mixture of clay and of gravel . [The whole place]353-the whole place was very sloppy from the rain which had fallen through the night . [The garden]354-the garden was bounded by a three - foot brick wall with a fringe of wood rails upon the top , and against this wall was leaning [a stalwart police constable]355-a stalwart police constable , surrounded by a small knot of loafers , who craned [their]356-their necks and strained [their]356-their eyes in the vain hope of catching some glimpse of the proceedings within .

[I]0-i had imagined that [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes would at once have hurried into [the house]1453-the house and plunged into a study of the mystery . Nothing appeared to be further from [his]110-holmes intention . With an air of nonchalance which , under the circumstances , seemed to [me]0-i to border upon affectation , [he]110-holmes lounged up and down [the pavement]358-the pavement , and gazed vacantly at the ground , the sky , [the opposite houses]359-the opposite houses and the line of railings . Twice [he]110-holmes stopped , and once [I]0-i saw [him]110-holmes smile , and heard [him]110-holmes utter an exclamation of satisfaction . There were many marks of footsteps upon the wet clayey soil , but since [the police]362-the police had been coming and going over it , [I]0-i was unable to see how [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion could hope to learn anything from it . Still [I]0-i had had such extraordinary evidence of the quickness of [his]110-holmes perceptive faculties , that [I]0-i had no doubt that [he]110-holmes could see a great deal which was hidden from [me]0-i .

[A short passage]372-a short passage , bare planked and dusty , led to [the kitchen and offices]373-the kitchen and offices . Two doors opened out of [it]372-a short passage to the left and to the right . [One of these]374-one of these had obviously been closed for many weeks . The other belonged to [the dining - room]375-the dining - room , which was [the apartment in which the mysterious affair had occurred]376-the apartment in which the mysterious affair had occurred . [Holmes]110-holmes walked in , and [I]0-i followed [him]110-holmes with that subdued feeling at [my]0-i heart which the presence of death inspires .

It was [a large square room]377-a large square room , looking all the larger from the absence of all furniture . A vulgar flaring paper adorned the walls , but [it]378-it was blotched in places with mildew , and here and there great strips had become detached and hung down , exposing the yellow plaster beneath . Opposite the door was a showy fireplace , surmounted by a mantelpiece of imitation white marble . On one corner of this was stuck the stump of a red wax candle . The solitary window was so dirty that the light was hazy and uncertain , giving a dull grey tinge to everything , which was intensified by the thick layer of dust which coated [the whole apartment]379-the whole apartment .

All these details [I]0-i observed afterwards . At present [my]0-i attention was centred upon the single grim motionless figure which lay stretched upon the boards , with vacant sightless eyes staring up at the discoloured ceiling . It was that of [a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age , middle - sized , broad shouldered , with crisp curling black hair , and a short stubbly beard . [He]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age was dressed in a heavy broadcloth frock coat and waistcoat , with light - coloured trousers , and immaculate collar and cuffs . A top hat , well brushed and trim , was placed upon the floor beside [him]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age . [His]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age hands were clenched and [his]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age arms thrown abroad , while [his]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age lower limbs were interlocked as though [his]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age death struggle had been a grievous one . On [his]380-a man about forty - three or forty - four years of age rigid face there stood an expression of horror , and as it seemed to [me]0-i , of hatred , such as [I]0-i have never seen upon human features . This malignant and terrible contortion , combined with the low forehead , blunt nose , and prognathous jaw gave [the dead man]381-the dead man a singularly simious and ape - like appearance , which was increased by [his]381-the dead man writhing , unnatural posture . [I]0-i have seen death in many forms , but never has it appeared to [me]0-i in a more fearsome aspect than in [that dark grimy apartment]382-that dark grimy apartment , which looked out upon one of [the main arteries of suburban [London]2-london]383-the main arteries of suburban london .

[Lestrade]119-lestrade , lean and ferret - like as ever , was standing by the doorway , and greeted [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion and [myself]0-i .

" This case will make a stir , [sir]1431-sir , "[119-lestrade] [he]119-lestrade remarked . " It beats anything [I]130-gregson have seen , and [I]130-gregson am no chicken . "[130-gregson]

" There is no clue ? "[119-lestrade] said [Gregson]130-gregson .

" None at all , "[110-holmes] chimed in [Lestrade]119-lestrade .

[Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes approached the body , and , kneeling down , examined it intently . " [You]1431-sir are sure that there is no wound ? "[385-both detectives] [he]110-holmes asked , pointing to numerous gouts and splashes of blood which lay all round .

"[0-i]

" That seems simple enough , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; " but how about [the other man]1532-the other man 's height ? "[110-holmes]

" Why , the height of [a man , in nine cases out of ten]1533-a man , in nine cases out of ten , can be told from the length of [his]1533-a man , in nine cases out of ten stride . " The finger nails and the Trichinopoly , "[110-holmes] [I]0-i suggested .

" The writing on the wall was done with [a man]226-a man 's forefinger dipped in blood . [I]0-i gathered up some scattered ash from the floor . It was dark in colour and flakey - such an ash as is only made by a Trichinopoly . [I]0-i have made a special study of cigar ashes - in fact , [I]0-i have written a monograph upon the subject . "[0-i]

" [I]243-my companion 'll tell [you]1556-you one other thing , "[243-my companion] [he]243-my companion said . " That 's [Audley Court]32-audley court in there , "[428-our driver] [he]428-our driver said , pointing to a narrow slit in the line of dead - coloured brick . " [You]424-we 'll find [me]434-the constable here when [you]424-we come back . "[434-the constable]

[Audley Court]32-audley court was not [an attractive locality]429-an attractive locality . [The narrow passage]430-the narrow passage led [us]424-we into [a quadrangle paved with flags and lined by sordid dwellings]431-a quadrangle paved with flags and lined by sordid dwellings . On enquiry [we]424-we found that [the constable]434-the constable was in bed , and [we]424-we were shown into [a little front parlour]435-a little front parlour to await [his]434-the constable coming .

[He]434-the constable appeared presently , looking a little irritable at being disturbed in [his]434-the constable slumbers . " [I]110-holmes made [my]110-holmes report at [the office]1570-the office , "[110-holmes] [he]434-the constable said .

[Holmes]110-holmes took a half - sovereign from [his]110-holmes pocket and played with it pensively . " [We]424-we thought that [we]424-we should like to hear it all from [your]110-holmes own lips , "[434-the constable] [he]110-holmes said .

" [I]434-the constable shall be most happy to tell [you]110-holmes anything [I]434-the constable can , "[434-the constable] [the constable]434-the constable answered with [his]434-the constable eyes upon the little golden disk .

" Just let [us]424-we hear it all in [your]110-holmes own way as it occurred . "[132-rance]

[Rance]132-rance sat down on the horsehair sofa , and knitted [his]132-rance brows as though determined not to omit anything in [his]132-rance narrative .

" [I]132-rance 'll tell it [ye]110-holmes from the beginning , "[132-rance] [he]132-rance said . " [My]243-my companion time is from ten at night to six in the morning . At eleven there was a fight at [the ' White Hart ']1571-the ' white hart ' ; but bar that all was quiet enough on the beat . At one o'clock it began to rain , and [I]243-my companion met [Harry Murcher]137-murcher - [him]137-murcher who has the Holland Grove beat - and [we]424-we stood together at the corner of [Henrietta Street]35-henrietta street a - talkin ' . Presently - maybe about two or a little after - [I]243-my companion thought [I]243-my companion would take a look round and see that all was right down [the Brixton Road]25-the brixton road . It was precious dirty and lonely . Not [a soul]1572-a soul did [I]243-my companion meet all the way down , though [a cab or two]1573-a cab or two went past [me]243-my companion . When [I]243-my companion got to the door - - "[243-my companion]

" [You]132-rance stopped , and then walked back to the garden gate , "[243-my companion] [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion interrupted . " What did [you]132-rance do that for ? "[132-rance]

[Rance]132-rance gave a violent jump , and stared at [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes with the utmost amazement upon [his]132-rance features .

" Why , that 's true , [sir]1431-sir , "[132-rance] [he]132-rance said ; " though how [you]1431-sir come to know it , [Heaven]111-heaven only knows . " [I]110-holmes am rather in the dark still . It is true that the description of [this man]287-this man tallies with [your]110-holmes idea of the second party in this mystery . " The ring , [man]1348-man , the ring : that was what [he]287-this man came back for . [I]110-holmes might not have gone but for [you]1519-doctor , and so have missed the finest study [I]110-holmes ever came across : a study in scarlet , eh ? Why should n't [we]443-we use a little art jargon . There 's the scarlet thread of murder running through the colourless skein of life , and [our]443-we duty is to unravel it , and isolate it , and expose every inch of it . And now for lunch , and then for [Norman Neruda]136-norman neruda . [Her]447-this amateur bloodhound attack and [her]447-this amateur bloodhound bowing are splendid . What 's that little thing of [Chopin]139-chopin 's [she]447-this amateur bloodhound plays so magnificently : Tra - la - la - lira - lira - lay . "[110-holmes]

Leaning back in the cab , [this amateur bloodhound]447-this amateur bloodhound carolled away like a lark while [I]0-i meditated upon the many - sidedness of the human mind .

[Our]448-our morning 's exertions had been too much for [my]0-i weak health , and [I]0-i was tired out in the afternoon . After [Holmes]110-holmes ' departure for the concert , [I]0-i lay down upon the sofa and endeavoured to get a couple of hours ' sleep . It was a useless attempt . [My]0-i mind had been too much excited by all that had occurred , and the strangest fancies and surmises crowded into it . Every time that [I]0-i closed [my]0-i eyes [I]0-i saw before [me]0-i the distorted baboon - like countenance of [the murdered man]449-the murdered man . So sinister was the impression which that face had produced upon [me]0-i that [I]0-i found it difficult to feel anything but gratitude for [him]449-the murdered man who had removed [its owner]450-its owner from [the world]1398-the world . If ever [human features]452-human features bespoke vice of the most malignant type , they were certainly those of [Enoch J. Drebber]123-drebber , of [Cleveland]23-cleveland . Still [I]0-i recognized that justice must be done , and that the depravity of [the victim]453-the victim was no condonement in the eyes of the law .

The more [I]0-i thought of it the more extraordinary did [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion 's hypothesis , that [the man]1387-the man had been poisoned , appear . [I]0-i remembered how [he]243-my companion had sniffed [his]243-my companion lips , and had no doubt that [he]243-my companion had detected something which had given rise to the idea . Then , again , if not poison , what had caused [the man]1387-the man 's death , since there was neither wound nor marks of strangulation ? But , on the other hand , whose blood was that which lay so thickly upon the floor ? There were no signs of a struggle , nor had [the victim]453-the victim any weapon with which [he]453-the victim might have wounded [an antagonist]458-an antagonist . As long as all these questions were unsolved , [I]0-i felt that sleep would be no easy matter , either for [Holmes]110-holmes or [myself]0-i . [His]110-holmes quiet self - confident manner convinced [me]0-i that [he]110-holmes had already formed a theory which explained all the facts , though what it was [I]0-i could not for an instant conjecture .

[He]110-holmes was very late in returning - so late , that [I]0-i knew that the concert could not have detained [him]110-holmes all the time . Dinner was on the table before [he]110-holmes appeared .

" It was magnificent , "[110-holmes] [he]110-holmes said , as [he]110-holmes took [his]110-holmes seat . " Do [you]0-i remember what [Darwin]140-darwin says about music ? [He]140-darwin claims that the power of producing and appreciating it existed among [the human race]1611-the human race long before the power of speech was arrived at . " And what may [your]474-the old woman address be ? "[474-the old woman] [I]0-i inquired , taking up a pencil .

It was close upon nine when [he]110-holmes set out . [I]0-i had no idea how long [he]110-holmes might be , but [I]0-i sat stolidly puffing at [my]0-i pipe and skipping over the pages of [Henri Murger]147-henri murger 's " Vie de Bohme . " [I]110-holmes would n't have [the Scotland Yarders]148-the scotland yarders know it for [the world]1398-the world , "[110-holmes] [he]110-holmes cried , dropping into [his]110-holmes chair ; " [I]0-i have chaffed [them]148-the scotland yarders so much that [they]148-the scotland yarders would never have let [me]0-i hear the end of it . " What is it then ? "[110-holmes] [I]0-i asked .

" Oh , [I]0-i do n't mind telling a story against [myself]0-i . That creature had gone a little way when [she]1663-she began to limp and show every sign of being foot - sore . Presently [she]1663-she came to a halt , and hailed [a four - wheeler]1664-a four - wheeler which was passing . [I]0-i managed to be close to [her]1663-she so as to hear the address , but [I]0-i need not have been so anxious , for [she]1663-she sang it out loud enough to be heard at the other side of [the street]329-the street , ' Drive to 13 , [Duncan Street]38-duncan street , [Houndsditch]39-houndsditch , ' [she]1663-she cried . This begins to look genuine , [I]0-i thought , and having seen [her]1663-she safely inside , [I]0-i perched [myself]0-i behind . That 's an art which [every detective]1666-every detective should be an expert at . Well , away [we]1667-we rattled , and never drew rein until [we]1667-we reached [the street in question]1668-the street in question . [I]0-i hopped off before [we]1667-we came to the door , and strolled down [the street]329-the street in an easy , lounging way . [I]0-i saw [the cab]1529-the cab pull up . [The driver]420-the driver jumped down , and [I]0-i saw [him]420-the driver open the door and stand expectantly . Nothing came out though . When [I]0-i reached [him]420-the driver [he]420-the driver was groping about frantically in [the empty cab]1672-the empty cab , and giving vent to the finest assorted collection of oaths that ever [I]0-i listened to . "[0-i]

"[110-holmes]

" [Old woman]1682-old woman be damned ! "[110-holmes] said [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes , sharply . " [We]1667-we were [the old women to be so taken in]1683-the old women to be so taken in . Now , [Doctor]1519-doctor , [you]1519-doctor are looking done - up . Take [my]487-me advice and turn in . "[487-me]

[I]0-i was certainly feeling very weary , so [I]0-i obeyed [his]110-holmes injunction . [I]0-i left [Holmes]110-holmes seated in front of the smouldering fire , and long into the watches of the night [I]0-i heard the low , melancholy wailings of [his]110-holmes violin , and knew that [he]110-holmes was still pondering over the strange problem which [he]110-holmes had set [himself]110-holmes to unravel .

The papers next day were full of the " Brixton Mystery , "[0-i] as [they]487-me termed it . [Each]488-each had a long account of the affair , and [some]489-some had leaders upon it in addition . There was some information in them which was new to [me]0-i . [I]0-i still retain in [my]0-i scrap - book numerous clippings and extracts bearing upon the case . Here is a condensation of a few of them : -

The _ Daily Telegraph _ remarked that in the history of crime there had seldom been a tragedy which presented stranger features . The German name of [the victim]453-the victim , the absence of all other motive , and the sinister inscription on the wall , all pointed to its perpetration by [political refugees]491-political refugees and [revolutionists]492-revolutionists . [The Socialists]493-the socialists had many branches in [America]43-america , and [the deceased]494-the deceased had , no doubt , infringed [their]493-the socialists unwritten laws , and been tracked down by [them]493-the socialists . After alluding airily to [the Vehmgericht]149-the vehmgericht , aqua tofana , [Carbonari]150-carbonari , [the Marchioness de Brinvilliers]151-the marchioness de brinvilliers , the Darwinian theory , the principles of [Malthus]152-malthus , and the Ratcliff Highway murders , the article concluded by admonishing [the Government]495-the government and advocating a closer watch over [foreigners]496-foreigners in [England]10-england .

The _ Standard _ commented upon the fact that lawless outrages of the sort usually occurred under a Liberal Administration . [They]497-they arose from the unsettling of the minds of [the masses]498-the masses , and the consequent weakening of all authority . [The deceased]494-the deceased was [an American gentleman who had been residing for some weeks in [the Metropolis]230-the metropolis]500-an american gentleman who had been residing for some weeks in the metropolis . [He]494-the deceased had stayed at [the boarding - house of [Madame Charpentier]153-madame charpentier , in [Torquay Terrace]44-torquay terrace , [Camberwell]45-camberwell]502-the boarding - house of madame charpentier , in torquay terrace , camberwell . [He]494-the deceased was accompanied in [his]494-the deceased travels by [[his]494-the deceased private secretary]503-his private secretary , [Mr. Joseph Stangerson]128-stangerson . The two bade adieu to [[their]504-their landlady]505-their landlady upon Tuesday , the 4th inst . , and departed to [Euston Station]46-euston station with the avowed intention of catching the [Liverpool]30-liverpool express . [They]504-their were afterwards seen together upon [the platform]506-the platform . Nothing more is known of [them]504-their until [Mr. Drebber]123-drebber 's body was , as recorded , discovered in [an empty house in [the Brixton Road]1475-the brixton road]507-an empty house in the brixton road , [many miles from [Euston]47-euston]509-many miles from euston . How [he]494-the deceased came [there]205-there , or how [he]494-the deceased met [his]494-the deceased fate , are questions which are still involved in mystery . Nothing is known of the whereabouts of [Stangerson]128-stangerson . [We]511-we are glad to learn that [Mr. Lestrade]119-lestrade and [Mr. Gregson]130-gregson , of [Scotland Yard]48-scotland yard , are both engaged upon the case , and it is confidently anticipated that [these well - known officers]512-these well - known officers will speedily throw light upon the matter .

The _ Daily News _ observed that there was no doubt as to the crime being a political one . The despotism and hatred of Liberalism which animated [the Continental Governments]49-the continental governments had had the effect of driving to [our]511-we shores [a number of men who might have made [excellent citizens]514-excellent citizens were [they]513-a number of men who might have made excellent citizens were they not soured by the recollection of all that they had undergone not soured by the recollection of all that [they]513-a number of men who might have made excellent citizens were they not soured by the recollection of all that they had undergone had undergone]513-a number of men who might have made excellent citizens were they not soured by the recollection of all that they had undergone . Among [these men]515-these men there was a stringent code of honour , any infringement of which was punished by death . Every effort should be made to find [the secretary]516-the secretary , [Stangerson]128-stangerson , and to ascertain some particulars of the habits of [the deceased]494-the deceased . A great step had been gained by the discovery of the address of [the house at which [he]494-the deceased had boarded]518-the house at which he had boarded - a result which was entirely due to the acuteness and energy of [[Mr. Gregson]130-gregson of [Scotland Yard]48-scotland yard]519-mr. gregson of scotland yard .

[Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes and [I]0-i read these notices over together at breakfast , and they appeared to afford [him]494-the deceased considerable amusement .

" That depends on how it turns out . "[0-i]

" Oh , bless [you]0-i , it does n't matter in the least . " ' On [your]1727-the daughter head be it , [Alice]160-alice ! " ' [Your]1727-the daughter best way is to make a clean breast of the facts , ' [I]130-gregson answered . ' Depend upon it , if [[your]1727-the daughter son]1745-your son is innocent [he]1743-my son will be none the worse . '[130-gregson]

" ' Perhaps , [Alice]160-alice , [you]160-alice had better leave [us]1746-us together , ' [she]370-the detective said , and [[her]370-the detective daughter]1722-her daughter withdrew . " ' It is [your]1727-the daughter wisest course , ' said [I.]130-gregson[130-gregson]

'[130-gregson]

" [The young man]1781-the young man volunteered a statement , in which [he]1781-the young man said that after following [Drebber]123-drebber some time , [the latter]1782-the latter perceived [him]1781-the young man , and took a cab in order to get away from [him]1781-the young man . [I]119-lestrade think the whole case fits together uncommonly well . What amuses [me]119-lestrade is to think of [Lestrade]119-lestrade , who had started off upon the wrong scent . It was indeed [Lestrade]119-lestrade , who had ascended the stairs while [we]547-we were talking , and who now entered [the room]259-the room . " It seemed to [me]110-holmes that [my]110-holmes sudden appearance might shake [his]123-drebber nerves and lead [him]123-drebber to say something unguarded . [The Boots]164-the boots pointed out the door to [me]110-holmes , and was about to go [downstairs]529-downstairs again when [I]110-holmes saw something that made [me]110-holmes feel sickish , in spite of [my]110-holmes twenty years ' experience . [I]110-holmes gave a cry , which brought [the Boots]164-the boots back . [He]123-drebber nearly fainted when [he]123-drebber saw it . The door was locked on the inside , but [we]1809-we put [our]1809-we shoulders to it , and knocked it in . [He]1811-a man in his nightdress was quite dead , and had been for some time , for [his]1811-a man in his nightdress limbs were rigid and cold . The cause of death was a deep stab in the left side , which must have penetrated the heart . And now comes the strangest part of the affair . What do [you]164-the boots suppose was above [the murdered man]449-the murdered man ? "[110-holmes]

[I]0-i felt a creeping of the flesh , and a presentiment of coming horror , even before [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes answered .

" The word RACHE , written in letters of blood , "[119-lestrade] [he]110-holmes said .

" That was it , "[119-lestrade] said [Lestrade]119-lestrade , in an awe - struck voice ; and [we]552-we were all silent for a while .

There was something so methodical and so incomprehensible about the deeds of [this unknown assassin]553-this unknown assassin , that it imparted a fresh ghastliness to [his]553-this unknown assassin crimes . [My]0-i nerves , which were steady enough on the field of battle tingled as [I]0-i thought of it .

" [The man]1387-the man was seen , "[119-lestrade] continued [Lestrade]119-lestrade . " [A milk boy]1816-a milk boy , passing on [his]1816-a milk boy way to [the dairy]1817-the dairy , happened to walk down [the lane which leads from [the mews at the back of [the hotel]232-the hotel]1819-the mews at the back of the hotel]1818-the lane which leads from the mews at the back of the hotel . [He]226-a man came down so quietly and openly that [the boy]1823-the boy imagined [him]226-a man to be [some carpenter or joiner at work in [the hotel]232-the hotel]1824-some carpenter or joiner at work in the hotel . [He]1387-the man took no particular notice of [him]1387-the man , beyond thinking in [his]1387-the man own mind that it was early for [him]1387-the man to be at work . [He]1387-the man has an impression that [the man]1387-the man was tall , had a reddish face , and was dressed in a long , brownish coat . [He]1387-the man must have stayed in [the room]259-the room some little time after the murder , for [we]1828-we found blood - stained water in the basin , where [he]1387-the man had washed [his]1387-the man hands , and marks on the sheets where [he]1387-the man had deliberately wiped [his]1387-the man knife . "[110-holmes]

[I]0-i glanced at [Holmes]110-holmes on hearing the description of [the murderer]1489-the murderer , which tallied so exactly with [his]110-holmes own . There was , however , no trace of exultation or satisfaction upon [his]110-holmes face .

" Did [you]0-i find nothing in [the room]259-the room which could furnish a clue to [the murderer]1489-the murderer ? "[0-i] [he]110-holmes asked .

" Nothing . [Stangerson]128-stangerson had [Drebber]123-drebber 's purse in [his]128-stangerson pocket , but it seems that this was usual , as [he]128-stangerson did all the paying . There was eighty odd pounds in it , but nothing had been taken . Whatever the motives of these extraordinary crimes , robbery is certainly not one of them . There were no papers or memoranda in [the murdered man]449-the murdered man 's pocket , except a single telegram , dated from [Cleveland]23-cleveland about a month ago , and containing the words , ' J. H. is in [Europe]59-europe . ' There was no name appended to this message . "[110-holmes]

" And there was nothing else ? "[0-i] [Holmes]110-holmes asked .

" Nothing of any importance . [The man]1387-the man 's novel , with which [he]1387-the man had read [himself]1387-the man to sleep was lying upon the bed , and [his]1387-the man pipe was on a chair beside [him]1387-the man . [Sherlock Holmes]110-holmes sprang from [his]110-holmes chair with an exclamation of delight .

" The last link , "[110-holmes] [he]110-holmes cried , exultantly . " [My]243-my companion case is complete . "[243-my companion]

[The two detectives]412-the two detectives stared at [him]110-holmes in amazement .

" [I]243-my companion have now in [my]243-my companion hands , "[243-my companion] [[my]0-i companion]243-my companion said , confidently , " all the threads which have formed such a tangle .
